sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Ximian Red Carpet is a program designed to help you manage the software you have on your computer. It can help you install, update, and remove programs, without making you keep track of dependencies and conflicts yourself. It works with the package management structures your operating systems already has, so you can use it alongside command-line tools without running into conflicts.

Red Carpet 2 has a number of important differences from the previous version. The appearance and interface have been completely overhauled, and there are several new features, such as the ability to manage software on remote systems, and the queue of pending actions which lets you choose installations, removals, and upgrades of software in multiple channels, then do everything at once.

One key difference is that, as of Red Carpet 2.0, Red Carpet the graphical tool is actually a client for rcd, the Red Carpet Daemon. Having two pieces means that you can update remote systems running the daemon. It also allows the use of alternate clients like the rc command line software management tool. Detailed information about rc and rcd are available in their man pages (standard manuals). You can read them by typing man rc or man rcd at the command line.

note.title: What is a Package?
note.para: Software for most versions of Linux is shipped as a package file, most commonly the rpm or deb format. Each package contains a set of files that constitute the software itself, plus additional information about what the software is, what requirements it has, and where it should be installed. Proper packaging makes software easier to install, upgrade, or remove, and can help manage the interdependencies among various programs.
Ximian Red Carpet supports the rpm (Red Hat Package Manager, used by many distributions), and the deb (Debian) package formats.

sect1.para: Ximian Red Carpet also gives you access to two important services from Ximian, Inc. The first service, Red Carpet Express, is for individuals, and offers access to special high-speed servers with faster connections, so you get better download rates. The other service, Ximian CorporateConnect, is aimed at businesses and workgroups that want to manage software deployment on a relatively large scale.
To find out more about using Red Carpet Express, read . For more about Red Carpet Enterprise visit the Ximian website.

listitem.para: The Ximian Red Carpet update and installation services require a network connection. You can still use Ximian Red Carpet to remove software or install local packages without using a network connection. To install from a file, select File Install Local Packages . For information on removing software, see .
To install, update, or remove software, you must enter your system's root password. If you do not have root privileges, you may only view the software installed on your system.

Ximian ships software for a limited number of operating systems. Not all software is available for all systems, although Ximian Red Carpet typically supports the broadest range of systems. The official list of supported systems is available at the Ximian Support Center.

sect1.para:
A Red Carpet transaction works like this:
Select software you wish to install, update, or remove.
Click the Run button to start the transactions.
Ximian Red Carpet will check to make sure it is possible to perform the requested actions without installing or removing other programs.
If necessary, Ximian Red Carpet will offer to add or remove additional software to satisfy requirements, giving you an opportunity to approve or cancel the actions.
When you approve, click Continue and the actions will be performed.

To start using Ximian Red Carpet, select
SystemSoftware Update from the menu panel, or type red-carpet at the command line.

sect1.title: Channels
sect1.para: Ximian Red Carpet organizes software into channels, groups of software sorted by origin or topic. "Red Hat 8.0," "Ximian Evolution Beta Snapshots," and "Ximian Desktop" are all channels. You can subscribe to different channels based on your interest in them. Software from channels to which you are not subscribed is not updated or installed.

To subscribe to a channel, select EditChannel Subscriptions or press the Channels button in the toolbar. A window will open to show you the list of available channels. Check the box next to a channel to subscribe.

sect1.title: Update
sect1.para: When you start Ximian Red Carpet it will show you a list of software packages that you can update. An update notice is only shown for software that you already have installed, that is in a channel to which you are subscribed, and for which there is a newer version than what you already have. New software, and new versions of software that you have but that is in a channel to which you do not subscribe, is not part of the update screen.
If you do not see any updates, make sure that you are subscribed to the right channels. See to learn how to adjust channel subscriptions.

To perform a simple update of your already installed software:
Select all the items in your update list by clicking on them one by one or choosing Edit Select All.
Mark the packages for installation by clicking the Mark for Installation button.
Click the Run Now button to have Ximian Red Carpet perform the updates.
You may also select individual packages for upgrade.

sect1.title: Install
sect1.para: To install new software, click the Search button. This will not display a list of all available software, because that could be a very long list. You must first search for the software you want to see. If you really wish to see every available piece of software, enter a blank search in the search box. Listing that much software may take some time.

To search for software, select one or more criteria for your search. You can choose:
Channel
Narrow your search to a specific channel. If you do not select anything, you will search in all channels to which you are subscribed.
Section
The type of software you are looking for, such as Productivit or Imaging.The default is to search in all sections.
Status
You can search for packages that are not installed, packages that are installed, packages that you have installed but for which a newer version is available, or for packages of any status. The default is to search for packages which you do not have installed.
Search Query
Enter a word or a few letters that describe the package and press Enter.

Each package is displayed with the following information:
Action
The action you are performing for this package. This entry will be blank if you are neither installing nor removing it. If you have selected an action, it will have an installation or removal icon. You can click on the blank space to perform an action (install a package if it is not installed, remove a packave if it is installed), or click on the icon to cancel the action.
Status
Package status indicates whether the package is installed or not installed. Status can also be older, meaning that the package displayed here is an older version than one you have installed, or newer, meaning that it is newer than your version.
Channel
The name of the channel in which this package is shipped.
Lock
The column with the lock icon indicates whether the package is cryptographically signed.
Package
The name of the software package.
Version
The version number of the package.

When you see an item you would like to install, click on it once to select it, then click the Mark For Installation button. The package installation will be added to the list of transactions displayed on the left of the window.
To remove an item from the list of pending transactions, select it and click Cancel or right-click on it and select Cancel.
Proceed to choose other software you would like to install or remove. When you are done choosing software, click the Run Now button in the toolbar at the top of the window.

sect1.title: Remove
sect1.para: To remove software, click the FIXME button. This will display a list of all software installed on your system. You can narrow your list by selecting criteria from the search toolbar.

When you see an item you would like to remove, click on it once to select it, then click the Mark For Removal button. The package removal will be added to the list of transactions displayed on the left of the window.
To remove an item from the list of pending transactions, select it and click Cancel or right-click on it and select Cancel.
Proceed to choose other software you would like to install or remove. When you are done choosing software, click the Run Now button in the toolbar at the top of the window.

sect1.title: Red Carpet Express
sect1.para: Red Carpet Express is a premium service that provides you with exclusive access to high speed download servers, plus additional software not available through the free service.
To sign up for Red Carpet Express, and more information about its benefits, visit http://store.ximian.com.

When you purchase a subscription, you will be given an activation key, which is a string of numbers and letters like 83ab2f90e821f000. To activate your subscription, select File Activate. A dialog will open and ask for your email address and the activation code.
You can turn Red Carpet Express and other premium services on or off by selecting Edit Preferences and, under the General section, clicking the Enable Premium Services checkbox.

sect1.title: Ximian Red Carpet Preferences
sect1.para: To open the preferences window, select Edit Preferences . The window has four tabbed pages: General, Cache, Daemon, and Advanced.

sect2.title: General Preferences
sect2.para:
You can set the following preferences here:
Server URL
The location of the Red Carpet server you are using.
Enable Premium Services
If you have already activated Red Carpet Express or Red Carpet Enterprise services, you can turn them on and off here.
Require Package Signatures
Ximian ships software with a cryprographic signature. Unless you absolutely trust your server (for example, you are using Red Carpet Enterprise) you should leave this setting on for security.
Maximum number of packages to download at once
If possible, Ximian Red Carpet will download several packages at once in order to make the best use of your network connection. If you have a very fast connection, you may wish to increase this number. If you are sharing your connection with others, you may wish to reduce it.
Use a Proxy
If your network uses an HTTP proxy, check this box, then enter the proxy URL. If necessary, also enter your username and password. Because Ximian Red Carpet does not depend on a particular desktop, this setting must be entered independently of the GNOME desktop proxy setting.

sect2.title: Download Cache Preferences
sect2.para:
Ximian Red Carpet stores downloaded files so that if you quit or cancel an operation, you can resume it quickly without downloading again. The Cache tab in the Preferences window lets you change cache handling behavior. Your options are:
Cache downloaded packages and metadata
If you don't want to cache anything, uncheck this box. It is normally on.
Location of cached data
Enter the location where you will save cached files.
Cache Expiration
You can the cache to empty after a certain number of days, or if its contents take up more than a certain amount of space. By default, this happens after 30 days or 300 MB. If you turn off cache expiration, packages will be kept until you delete them yourself by clicking the Empty Cache button.
At the bottom of the window, you can empty the package cache by clicking the Empty Cache button.

sect2.title: Advanced Red Carpet Preferences
sect2.para: The options available in this section are:

listitem.para: The dispatcher, or "magic" proxy, is used only in complex Red Carpet Enterprise deployments. If you are using one, your system administrator will give you a hostname to enter here.

When you upgrade or remove software, Ximian Red Carpet normally just deletes the old version. However, it is possible to "repackage" it, creating an archived version so you can switch back if necessary. Repackaging is time consuming and uses significant amounts of disk space.

varlistentry.term: Verify server SSL certificates with external authority

listitem.para: This setting demands that the Red Carpet server have an identity certificate which is verified by external authority organizations. An external certificate is expensive and most servers will not have one.
Check this box if your proxy or server insists on strict HTTP/1.0 protocol for communications.

Operation messages are saved to the file /var/log/rcd/rcd-messages depending upon the degree of importance assigned to them by the developer. A value of 1 will send only the messages that are flagged as most important; 6 will send every message, and 0 will send no messages.

Determines the amount of information sent to the central operating system log. Messages are sent depending upon the degree of importance assigned to them by the developer. A value of 1 will send only the messages that are flagged as most important; 6 will send every message, and 0 will send no messages.

sect2.para: If you require finer control over the operation of Ximian Red Carpet, you may wish to edit the configuration files, as described in the man pages for rc, rcd, and rcd.conf.

sect1.title: Using Red Carpet with Remote Systems
sect1.para: Ximian Red Carpet may be used with remote systems running the Red Carpet Daemon, rcd. You will need to have an account with the daemon on the remote system.

To add an account on the remote system, you must log in to that system as root, and use the rc user-add -U username -P password command to add a user. Then, you may administer the system using the rc command or the graphical red-carpet tool. For information on using the command line methods, type man rc.

To connect to a remote system, do the following:
Select FileConnect.
Click the Connect to a remote daemon button.
Enter the hostname and, if necessary, port for connection to the remote system.
Enter your user name and password.
Click the Connect button.
Once you are connected you can view and administer the system as you would a local one, in accordance with the privileges granted to your account.
